Award.AwardTitle: ATIP US-China Workshop on High-Performance Computing (HPC): Specialized Hardware Challenges and Advantages

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
ATIP requests support for a US-China Workshop on High-Performance Computing (HPC) emphasizing specialized hardware. The Workshop will include a significant set of presentations, posters, and panels from a delegation of Chinese academic, research laboratory, and industry experts as well as graduate students. Participants will address topics that include Government support for the research, development, and utilization of special purpose hardware, including GPU and self-developed processors; in addition, applications will also be stressed. Speakers from industry will provide perspectives of the importance of such hardware for real applications.
In addition, a special effort will be made to include HPC R&D developments in Hong Kong. Another important component will be a panel in which panelists and the audience identify topics that are suitable for collaborative (US-China) research and the mechanisms for developing those collaborations. A key aspect of the proposed Workshop will be the unique opportunity for members of the US research community to interact and have direct discussions with top Chinese scientists who will travel to the US to participate. A specific goal of the Workshop is to motivate the preparation of joint research proposals with researchers from both US and China.

There are many difficult problems associated with the development and use of high-performance computing (HPC). Important concerns include power, cost, programmability, and reliability, as well as the “traditional” requirement for highest performance. Recently, there has been a significant effort to utilize special purpose hardware which might be less expensive to purchase, operates at lower electrical costs, and performs better than more general purpose hardware.  The most recent trend takes this a step further with the incorporation of GPUs, processors that were initially developed for graphics engines and game consoles. These make programming more challenging, but offer excellent cost benefit. Developing countries such as China are very strongly attracted to this approach and have considerable experience exploiting it. Finally, China recently developed an energy efficient and low-cost general-purpose processor that is being incorporated into Chinese domestic HPC systems. Since these scenarios present unique research challenges, it is particularly important for US researchers to hear about such developments in China and to determine whether there are opportunities to improve US domestic research.
 
The Asian Technology Information Program (ATIP) held a US-China Workshop on High-Performance Computing (HPC) emphasizing specialized hardware, including a significant set of presentations, posters, and panels from a delegation of Chinese academic, research laboratory, and industry experts as well as graduate students. Participants spoke on topics such as Government support for the research, development, and utilization of special purpose hardware, including GPU and self-developed processors. Speakers from industry provided their perspective of the importance of such hardware for real applications. A panel of experts helped the audience identify topics suitable for collaborative (US-China) research and the mechanisms for developing those collaborations.

A key outcome of the proposed Workshop was the interaction between the US research community and the top Chinese scientists. ATIP’s workshop gave US scientists the opportunity to become acquainted with their Chinese colleagues, and encouraged the development of collaborations leading to joint research on especially difficult HPC problems of mutual interest. This approach is particularly important, because Chinese scientists are increasingly utilizing HPC while at the same time publishing only infrequently in English in international journals.  Further, when viewed from a Chinese perspective, the travel costs associated with participation in international meetings are very high. As a result, only a small elite set of Chinese researchers has the opportunity to travel abroad to interact with recognized scientists outside of China.
